Posts.Content: Aug 7, 2008 06:58AM theres126 wrote: Great idea about sitting in front of the leader!  I used to love to sit right in front, but I've gotten a bit more timid, the older I've gotten.   I actually think it started once I had kids.....  I wrote to the outfitters to see what they thought, and they said I could sit in the middle of the boat and not paddle, any time I needed a break!   I did go canoeing at a breast cancer retreat a couple of months ago (and paddled), but I was able to switch arms back and forth, which helped! Thanks everyone - and Binney - great pictures!!! Theresa
Posts.Title: White water rafting??? theres126 lvtwoqlt

Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2006 01:58PM theres126-2006Apr11 wrote: I didn't realize that I needed to be moisturizing! (I don't have lymphedema, but did have 5 sentinel nodes removed) I'll be flying next month, but guess I won't be able to moisturize, according to that message string.......
Posts.Title: Flying under the new guidelines for carry-ons Babyface theres126-2006Apr11

Posts.Content: theres126 wrote: Hi everyone- I don't have lymphedema, but I did have 5 lymph nodes removed during my mastectomy. We're hoping to do something special for my son as he heads off to his first year of college.  I thought we'd do something different, and white water rafting came to me, since we've never gone with the kids (and it's been years for us).  My question - is it possible to do, or is it a dumb idea after having lymph nodes removed? I do have a sleeve and gauntlet that I wear when flying. Should I wear them? Or, should I just bag the whole idea?     really wanted to do something memorable with him (and something that is actually fun for an 18 year old.....)  Thanks! Theresa  Dx 4/24/2006, IDC, <1cm, Stage IB, Grade 1, 0/5 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
